sources: Bord, Janet, and Colin Bord. The Secret Country: An interpretation of the folklore of ancient sites in the British Isles. (New York: Walker and Co., 1976), 115.
Bradley, Ian. Celtic Christianity: Making Myths and Chasing Dreams. New York: St. Martin’s Press, 1999.
Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: The polytheistic Celtic religion faced the possible eradication of its practices with the introduction of monotheistic Christianity. While Christian campaigns, like Martin of Tours' idol-smashing in France, contributed to the loss of continental Celtic material, it proved difficult to eliminate religious practices. Despite edicts targeting traditions of honoring Stones and Trees, like the Edict of Arles in 452 C.E. and the Council of Tours' recommendation of excommunication a century later, ancient customs persisted. Even as late as the Decree of Nantes in 658 C.E., people continued to seek out the old sites of worship and bishops were encouraged to remove and hide the stones still worshiped. Many of these sites had been in use for millennia, originating from pre-Celtic people. Ultimately, the church adopted a strategy from the earlier Roman invaders by proposing a version of the Interpretatio Romana. Pope Gregory in the seventh century advised that people should "take advantage of well-built temples by purifying them from devil-worship and dedicating them to the service of the true God." Hopeful that people would abandon their idolatry yet still visit their familiar places, it was possible for them to learn about and admire the true God. This new mindset permitted ancient customs to persist but rebranded them as church rituals. Despite this Christian expansion, pagan practices continued in certain regions, resulting in the Church of Scotland forming a committee in 1649 with the goal of eradicating "druidical customs" (see Druid) still maintained in some areas. Usually, Celtic customs were assimilated into Christianity, transforming former Celtic celebrations into Christian feasts, churches were constructed on ancient holy grounds, and pagan divinities became "canonized" as saints. In Ireland, this trend was maintained as ancient sites were dedicated to Christian practices. When contrasting Ireland with the other Celtic countries, literacy played an important role in preserving history.  Early written works of Irish literature were completed by Christian scholars including the Táin Bó Cuailnge. While it's possible some traditions and beliefs incompatible with Christian beliefs were changed or omitted, without the work of Christian scholars, even more Celtic customs would have been lost. Christianity's presence in Celtic religion retains a both a destructive and preservative relationship.
